results.title: The Lower depths
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Maxim Gorky’s ‘The Lower depths’ attracted two of cinema’s greatest practitioners to its pages. Just as Jean Renoir’s ‘Les Bas Fonds’ was a very French adaptation, so Kurosawa’s film is quite specifically Japanese, with Gorky’s Moscow slums transposing easily (and faithfully) to Kurosawa’s stylised Tokyo hovel. The resulting ensemble piece displays the director’s technical virtuosity and his ability to draw outstanding performances from his cast. Stars Toshiro Mifune. From the play by Maxim Gorky. Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: My fair lady
results.creator_credit: George Cukor, Jack L. Warner and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The dazzling film version of Lerner and Loewe’s acclaimed musical. Audrey Hepburn stars as the cockney flowergirl Eliza Doolittle who is trained by Professor Higgins (Rex Harrison) to pass as a duchess. Featuring sumptuous cinematography and costumes by Cecil Beaton, this is one of the most popular musicals ever filmed. Winner of eight Academy awards including Best Picture. The original musical is based on George Bernard Shaw’s “Pygmalion”.

results.title: Seven brides for seven brothers (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Stanley Donen, Jack Cummings and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Seven brides for seven brothers is a funny, romantic, physically lively movie musical. It represents a wonderful mix of story, characters, song, ideas and dancing. In Oregon, when Adam Pontipee brings a bride back to the farm after a visit to town, Milly finds that she has to be not only a wife, but also mother to her brothers-in-law. The six brothers listen to Adam’s story of the sobbin’ women and decide to steal brides for themselves. Starring Howard Keel and Jane Powell.

results.title: The Brothers Karamazov
results.creator_credit: Richard Brooks, Pandro S. Berman, Avon and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Based on Dostoyevsky’s masterful story of greed, vindictiveness and lust, “The Brothers Karamazov” brings 19th century Czarist Russia to life in a lavish dramatic production. Karamazov, is the father of four wildly disparate sons: a sterile intellectual, the saintly Alexey, an illegitimate schemer and the feckless oldest son, Dmitri who is in love with the same elusive woman as his father. They all stand to gain an inheritance from their father and together they weave a web of intrigue and murder. A wonderfully woven tale of sin and salvation, the film stars Yul Brynner, Maria Schell, Lee J. Cobb, Claire Bloom, Richard Basehart and William Shatner.

results.title: Nadja
results.creator_credit: Michael Almereyda, Amy Hobby, Mary Sweeney and Kino Link Company
results.brief_description:
Revisiting the vampire legend director/writer Michael Almereyda creates a modern day setting for several sexy undead creatures of the night. Elina Lowensohn plays the title role - a New York based vampire who is celebrating the demise of her father, and is hoping that her new life will encompass the attractive Lucy. Unfortunately Lucy is married to the nephew of a vampire hunter who is hell-bent on conquering Nadja. Aesthetically the film is an alluring mix of 35 mm footage and black-and-white, low-budget Pixelvision video. As an art film, the form is impressive but the narrative wanes at key moments, leaving an overall sense of a film that wavers inconsistently between a surrealist

Credits: Producer, Mary Sweeney, Amy Hobby ; director, writer, Michael Almereyda ; photography, Jim De Nault ; music, Simon Fisher Turner ; editing, David Leonard.
Cast: Elina Lowensohn, Suzy Amis, Galaxy Craze, Martin Donovan, Peter Fonda, Karl Geary.

results.title: Love serenade
results.creator_credit: Shirley Barrett, Mandy Walker, Jan Chapman, AFFC and Saddleback Productions
results.brief_description:
Two bored sisters, Dimity and Vicki-Ann, live in the small country town of Sunray. Their new neighbour, a brooding self-centered type, formerly star D.J. of a drive-time programme on Brisbane radio, threatens to turn the sisters’ world upside down. Dimity and Vicki-Ann find themselves in competition for his affections as each develops a severe crush on the aging Lothario with a predilection for 70’s music and young women. Awards: Cannes International Film Festival 1996: Camera d’Or for Shirley Barrett. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Jan Chapman ; director, writer, Shirley Barrett ; photography, Mandy Walker.
Cast: Miranda Otto, Rebecca Frith, George Shevtsov, John Alansu.

results.title: The Jungle book (plus special effects production)
results.creator_credit: Zoltan Korda, Alexander Korda and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: A young boy returns to his native village attempting to adapt to human customs and his adopted family. The discovery of a coin in the jungle awakens the greed of the village people who hope to discover a legendary buried treasure. Disillusioned by the greed and violence of humanity he retreats to his loyal and trusted friends … the beasts of the jungle. Stars Sabu. Based on Rudyard Kipling’s “Jungle book”. This version includes special effects techniques and production outtakes.

results.title: Five times dizzy. - Episodes 7-12.
results.creator_credit: John Eastway, Tom Jeffrey, Australian Children's Television Foundation, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Samson Film Services
results.brief_description: The final three episodes in the dramatisation of Nadia Wheatley’s award winning book about a family of Greek immigrants in Sydney’s Newtown, their homesick grandmother and the inhabitants of the street in which they live, as seen through the eyes of Mareka, the young daughter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Eastway, Tom Jeffrey, Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Samson Film Services

results.title: Five times dizzy. - Episodes 1-6.
results.creator_credit: John Eastway, Tom Jeffrey, Australian Children's Television Foundation, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Samson Film Services
results.brief_description: The first three episodes in a dramatisation of Nadia Wheatley’s award winning book. Mareka would be quite happy in the milk bar in Newtown, even though it is so far from Greece, if it wasn’t for the Wilson kids giving her a hard time. But her Yaya, her grandmother, has only recently arrived in Australia and feels lost and unhappy. If only Mareka could find her Yaya something to do. Then she has an idea. But it’s such a big idea she feels dizzy.

results.title: Several days in the life of I.I. Oblomov
results.brief_description:
Oblomov is based on a gently satirical novel by Ivan Goncharov set in the mid-nineteenth century about an absentee landlord who stays in bed because he cannot find a convincing reason for getting up. He has tried getting up in the past but sees no reason to go on with it. Moreover, as a man of means he is in the position of being able to choose not to go on with it. ‘(An) engagingly adapted parable of a privileged recluse being reluctantly dragged towards light, life and love…As the tardily socialised eternally indecisive Oblomov, Tabakov invests sloth with a winning seductiveness’ (Paul Taylor in Time Out). Another print also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Nikita Mikhalkov ; script, A. Adabashian, N. Mikhalkov ; photography, Pavel Lebeshev ; music, E. Artemiev.
Cast: Oleg Tabakov, Yuri Bogatyryov, Andrei Popov, Yelena Solovei.
